p: Recently, retroviral restriction factors have drawn the attention of researchers. HIV-1 infection and replication is restricted by a number of host proteins, known as restriction factors, that interfere with the critical processes involved in the life cycle of retroviruses. Four of these are sterile alpha motif domain-containing protein 1 (SAMHDI) [ 23, 24, 25], apolipoprotein B mRNA editing enzyme catalytic subunit 3G (APOBEC3G) [ 26], viperin [ 27], and tetherin [ 28]. These restriction factors inhibit viral replication and the production of new progeny virions by preventing reverse transcription, by inducing viral DNA to mutate, and by promoting TLR 7- and TLR9-mediated synthesis of type I IFN by plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs).
